title: 107_hr5241
content: The Act titled "Lifespan Respite Care Act of 2002" amends the Public Health Service Act by adding a new section on Lifespan Respite Care. This section includes findings and purposes related to respite care. Congress finds that millions of individuals in the United States provide care for family members with chronic illnesses or disabilities, including children with special needs and those living with relatives due to parental inability or unwillingness to care for them. Approximately 6,000,000 children in the United States live with a grandparent or other relative due to parental inability or unwillingness to care for them. Additionally, an estimated 165,000 children with disabilities live with foster care parents, and nearly 4,000,000 individuals of all ages with mental retardation or developmental disabilities live with their families. Approximately 25% of the Nation's elders have multiple chronic disabling conditions, requiring assistance with daily needs. Around 600,000 Americans die at home each year, often relying on extensive family caregiving before their deaths. Almost 25% of the Nation's elders have multiple chronic disabling conditions, requiring help with daily needs. Approximately 600,000 Americans die at home annually, often depending on family caregiving. 42% of individuals in the US needing daily living assistance are under 65. Insufficient resources exist to replace family caregivers with paid workers. Approximately 75 percent of family caregivers are women, and if family caregivers had to be replaced with paid services, it would cost around $200 billion annually. The family caregiver role is personally rewarding but can lead to emotional, physical, and financial hardship. Approximately 75 percent of family caregivers are women. Family caregivers often struggle with emotional, physical, and financial hardships. They lack information on available respite care and face insufficient programs primarily targeting lower income populations and elderly caregivers. Family caregivers, especially women, often struggle to find information on available respite care programs. These programs are insufficient and primarily cater to lower income and elderly caregivers, leaving many without adequate support. Additionally, there is a limited number of respite care programs that face challenges in recruiting trained workers. The purposes of this title are to encourage States to establish State and local lifespan respite care programs, improve respite care information dissemination to family caregivers, provide respite care services, and promote innovative approaches. The purpose of this title is to encourage States to establish lifespan respite care programs, improve respite care information dissemination to family caregivers, provide respite care services, and promote innovative approaches to respite care delivery. The purpose of this title is to encourage States to establish lifespan respite care programs, improve respite care information dissemination to family caregivers, provide respite care services, and promote innovative approaches to respite care delivery, including respite care worker and volunteer recruitment and training programs, training programs for family caregivers, evaluative research on effective respite care services, and dissemination of results and findings from related programs and research projects. The purpose of this title is to encourage States to establish lifespan respite care programs, improve respite care information dissemination to family caregivers, provide respite care services, promote innovative approaches to respite care delivery, support evaluative research on effective respite care services, and disseminate results and findings from related programs and research projects. The term 'condition' in this title includes Alzheimer's disease, developmental disabilities, mental retardation, physical disabilities, chronic illness (such as cancer), behavioral and emotional conditions, cognitive impairments, and situations with a high risk of abuse or neglect. LIFESPAN RESPITE CARE GRANTS AND COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS." The section aims to expand respite care services for family caregivers, improve dissemination and coordination, and enhance access and quality of services to reduce caregiver strain. The Secretary is authorized to award grants to eligible recipients for this purpose. The Secretary may award grants to eligible recipients for expanding respite care services to family caregivers, in cooperation with various agencies to reduce caregiver strain. The Secretary, through the Maternal and Child Health Bureau, will coordinate respite care services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs.
